name: Carriage

description: When measuring distance, the first diagonal counts as 1 square, the second counts as 2 squares, the third counts as 1, the fourth as 2, and so on. (If it helps, you can think of a diagonal as a distance of 1.5 squares.) You can’t move diagonally past a corner (even by taking a 5-foot step). You can move diagonally past a creature, even an opponent. You can also move diagonally past other impassable obstacles, such as pits.
name: Diagonals

description: When it’s important to determine the closest square or creature to a location, if two squares or creatures are equally close, randomly determine which one counts as closest by rolling a die. Moving through a Square
name: Closest Creature

description: You can’t end your movement in the same square as another creature unless it is helpless.
name: Ending Your Movement

description: A Fine, Diminutive, or Tiny creature can move into or through an occupied square. The creature provokes attacks of opportunity when doing so.
name: Very Small Creature

description: Any creature can move through a square occupied by a creature three size categories larger than it is. A gnome (Small), for example, can run between the legs of a cloud giant (Huge). A big creature can move through a square occupied by a creature three size categories smaller than it is. A cloud giant, for example, (This is often significant for creatures whose space fills more than one square, such as a giant.) can step over a gnome. Flying and incorporeal creatures are not hampered by difficult
name: Square Occupied by Creature Three Sizes Larger or Smaller

description: Some creatures break the above rules. terrain. For example, a gelatinous cube fills the squares it occupies to a
name: Designated Exceptions

description: Like difficult terrain, obstacles can hamper move- height of 15 feet. A creature that completely fills the squares it ment. If an obstacle hampers movement but doesn’t completely occupies cannot be moved past, even with the Tumble skill or block it, such as a low wall or a deadfall of branches, each obstructed similar special abilities. square or obstacle between squares counts as 2 squares of move- ment. You must pay this cost to cross the barrier, in addition to the Terrain and Obstacles cost to move into the square on the other side. If you don’t have The rules presented so far in this section assume that you’re moving sufficient movement to cross the barrier and move into the square through an area clear of obstacles or difficult terrain. However, in on the other side, you can’t cross the barrier. Some obstacles may dungeons and wilderness areas, that’s often not the case. also require a skill check to cross (such as Climb of Jump).
name: Obstacles

description: Difficult terrain, such as rubble, an uneven On the other hand, some obstacles, such as floor-to-ceiling walls, cave floor, thick undergrowth, and the like, hampers movement. block movement entirely. A character can’t move through a Each square of difficult terrain counts as 2 squares of movement. blocking obstacle. (Each diagonal move into a difficult terrain square counts as 3 Flying and incorporeal creatures can avoid most obstacles though squares.) You can’t run or charge across difficult terrain. a floor-to-ceiling wall blocks a flying creature as well as a landbound creature. If you occupy squares with different kinds of terrain, you can
name: Difficult Terrain

description: In some cases, you may have to squeeze into or move only as fast as the most difficult terrain you occupy will allow. through an area that isn’t as wide as the space you take up. (This is particularly true for creatures whose space fills more than one square, such as a giant.) You can squeeze through or into a space that is at least half as wide as your normal space. For instance, an ogre (whose space is 10 feet, or 2 squares, wide) can squeeze through or into a space at least 5 feet (1 square) wide. Each move into or through a narrow space counts as if it were 2 squares, and while squeezed in a narrow space you take a –4 penalty on attack rolls and a –4 penalty to AC. When a Large creature (which normally takes up four squares) squeezes into a space that’s one square wide, the creature’s miniature figure occupies two squares, centered on the line between the two squares. For a bigger creature, center the creature likewise in the area it squeezes into. A creature can squeeze past an opponent while moving but it can’t end its movement in an occupied square. To squeeze through or into a space less than half your space’s width, you must use the Escape Artist skill (page 73). You can’t attack while using Escape Artist to squeeze through or into a narrow space, you take a –4 penalty to AC, and you lose any Dexterity bonus to AC. Special Movement Rules These rules cover special movement situations.
name: Squeezing

description: Some- times a character ends its movement while moving through a space where it’s not allowed to stop. For example, you might incur an attack of opportunity from a monk while moving through a friend’s square and become stunned. When that happens, put your miniature in the last legal position you occupied, or the closest legal position, if there’s a legal position that’s closer. 148 :8 RETPAHC TABMOC creatures normally. Since they have no natural reach, they do not
name: Accidentally Ending Movement in an Illegal Space

This is an exception to the general rule that two they aren’t in adjacent squares. name: Double Movement Cost

description: A low obstacle (such as a wall no attack helpless or pinned defenders. name: Low Obstacles and Cover

description: You can use cover to make a Hide such a creature, you can pick any of the squares it occupies to check. Without cover, you usually need concealment (see below) to determine if it has cover against you. make a Hide check. 151 COMBAT CHAPTER 8:
name: Cover and Hide Checks

description: As with cover, it’s usually not worth differentiating between more degrees of concealment than described above. However, the DM may rule that certain situ- ations provide more or less than typical concealment, and modify the miss chance accordingly. For instance, a light fog might only provide a 10% miss chance, while near-total darkness could provide a 40% miss chance (and a +10 circumstance bonus on Hide checks). FLANKING When making a melee attack, you get a +2 flanking bonus if your opponent is threatened by a character or creature friendly to you on the opponent’s opposite border or opposite corner. When in doubt about whether two friendly characters flank an opponent in the middle, trace an imaginary line between the two friendly characters’ centers. If the line passes through opposite borders of the opponent’s space (including corners of those bor- ders), then the opponent is flanked.
name: Varying Degrees of Concealment

description: If a flanker takes up more than 1 square, it gets the flanking bonus if any square it occupies counts for flanking. Only a creature or character that threatens the defender can help an attacker get a flanking bonus. Creatures with a reach of 0 feet can’t flank an opponent. HELPLESS DEFENDERS A helpless opponent is someone who is bound, sleeping, paralyzed, unconscious, or otherwise at your mercy.
name: Exception

For example, a cleric with the Fire domain can turn or destroy water creatures (as if he were a good cleric turning undead) and rebuke or READY command fire creatures (as if he were an evil cleric rebuking The ready action lets you prepare to take an action later, after your undead). description: A character with a Constitution score of 9 or higher can run ment scales, creatures generally walk, hustle, or run. for a minute without a problem. Generally, a character can run for a

description: In a day of normal walking, a character walks for 8 hours. The rest of the daylight time is spent making and breaking Table 9–6: Mounts and Vehicles camp, resting, and eating. Mount/Vehicle Per Hour Per Day A character can walk for more than 8 hours in a day by making a Mount (carrying load) forced march. For each hour of marching beyond 8 hours, a Con- Light horse or light warhorse 6 miles 48 miles stitution check (DC 10, +2 per extra hour) is required. If the check Light horse (151–450 lb.)1 4 miles 32 miles fails, the character takes 1d6 points of nonlethal damage. A character Light warhorse (231–690 lb.)1 4 miles 32 miles who takes any nonlethal damage from a forced march becomes Heavy horse or heavy warhorse 5 miles 40 miles fatigued. Eliminating the nonlethal damage also eliminates the Heavy horse (201–600 lb.)1 3-1/2 miles 28 miles Heavy warhorse (301–900 lb.)1 3-1/2 miles 28 miles fatigue. It’s possible for a character to march into unconsciousness Pony or warpony 4 miles 32 miles by pushing himself too hard. Pony (76–225 lb.)1 3 miles 24 miles Mounted Movement: A mount bearing a rider can move at a Warpony (101–300 lb.)1 3 miles 24 miles hustle. The damage it takes when doing so, however, is lethal Donkey or mule 3 miles 24 miles damage, not nonlethal damage. The creature can also be ridden in a Donkey (51–150 lb.)1 2 miles 16 miles forced march, but its Constitution checks automatically fail, and, Mule (231–690 lb.)1 2 miles 16 miles again, the damage it takes is lethal damage. Mounts also become Dog, riding 4 miles 32 miles fatigued when they take any damage from hustling or forced Dog, riding (101–300 lb.)1 3 miles 24 miles marches.
